content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very cool and unique, not too difficult but challenging, and very fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash - not too complex, but still challenging, especially in reverse mode. Let it be.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked this puzzle. I think it is not too easy or too hard, it can be solved relatively fast in fastest and reverse, in my opinion it is good for shortest, because there are many different ways to solve this puzzle and it is not clear what is shortest way. Thing I think you should improve is test cases for "diagonal", I think points are always sorted and with same difference between two consecutive points, correct me if I am wrong. Considering everything I think this puzzle should be added to clash of code.

I tried to code it, but it was too hard for me, to do it in time.

For a clash of code it has to be easier, maybe skip the errors and just let people check for vertical, diagonal or horizontal.

Your last 2 Testcases have the same name.

Surprisingly this was more challenging to implement than expected. It's an excellent puzzle in my opinion. Maybe I would remove the test with two "0 0" points because it's not very clear what should be the output in this case. Also did you make the points equal distance on purpose? How about adding tests like:
0 0
6 2
21 7
9 3
Hi, it's a nice challenge but to further avoid binary (or ternary) output maybe you should print the first point breaking the line if it's not a straight line.
Will be adjusting the challenge soon to instead of printing true, you have to print either diagonal, horizontal or vertical.
As said 5DN1L, avoid binary output. People can get 5°% score just with print("true") program

Please read the contribution guidelines here and adhere to them:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
In particular,
1. Do not use the same test case as a validator.
2. Avoid binary output (i.e. there are only two choices of outputs).
Hey, thank you very much for the feedback. Good idea, I'll edit the tests and code shortly.
The 0 0/1 1 points will be removed. The test that you gave as an example exists, it's in fact the last one. Once again, thanks for the feedback. ^^

Hey, thank you for your feedback. The solution can be coded with only a couple of lines. There are also more possible solutions than the one I provided.

Could you explain how it'd be easier if you remove the errors?

I'll edit the last testcase, thanks for letting me know.

I checked your solution, and the funny thing is I tried to do the same thing, but it didnt work for me. (In JS)

Also if the Error is in the 1st or 2nd coord your solution fails.

I am no pro and just doing this to learn and get better. Just said, I couldnt do this in time. If you know the error isnt in the 1st two coords this is way easier, was never stated in the description, but your solution is based on this.
Ah thanks! I'll add this to the description.
